content: just weave it you can use fingering sport dk or worsted weight yarn allow approx 100m/110yds each of cc and mc for a single loop allow approx 200m/220yds each of cc and mc for a double loop for the cc you can use variegated or striping yarn for interesting effects for the mc you can use solid or even another variegated or striping yarn but make sure you have good contrast between all colours you don t need to knit to a specific gauge just use a needle size that makes a nice fabric in the pattern stitch you will probably use 1 or 2 sizes larger than the recommended handspun and drops soft tweed on needle size for the mc yarn because 4 5mm/us7 light mc you want a nice lofty fabric not a dense one your mc can be light or dark you can see other examples by looking at the if you knit more tightly you may wish projects on ravelry to cast on more stitches and allow more yardage for the same size abbreviations k = knit kfb = knit into the front and back loops p = purl creates 1 new stitch st s = stitch es sl = slip all sts are slipped purlwise rs/ws = right/ wrong side wyif = with yarn in front mc/cc = main/ contrast wyib = with yarn in back colour k2tog = knit 2 sts together just weave it by susan ashcroft for personal non-commercial use only 1 cast on using provisional cast on the method i use is to make a crochet chain with waste yarn and then pull up a loop with the mc in each of the purl bumps provisional crochet 2 cast-on in the cast on bind off book tip i find using a larger crochet hook to make the chain makes it much easier to pull up the stitches e g i would use up to 6mm hook for 4 5mm knitting needle option if you prefer you can use a cable cast-on and then stitch together the ends but you will get a ridge on the inside of the cowl sizing - i used 52 sts for a 17cm/7 wide strip gauge of 20 sts per 10cm/4 - if you like you can add or deduct multiples of 4 e g 48 or 56 notes - you will change yarns every 2 row bring the yarn up from underneath - you will need to untangle the yarns from time to time as you work row 1 purl bumps will form on the rs but they will disappear once you remove the provisional cast-on see pg 3 row 1 cc - rs - kfb *sl1 wyif k1 sl1 wyib k1 repeat from * to the last 3 sts sl1 wyif k2tog row 2 - ws - sl1 wyif p2 *sl1 wyif p3 repeat from * to the last stitch sl1 wyif row 3 mc - rs - kfb *k3 sl1 wyib repeat from
